comment.text: Great vibes and the way the sun hit my table was immaculate. Food is on point and service is great. Only 4 stars because the chairs in the main seating area aren't conducive to being there a while. May very well be intentional, but my butt fell asleep waiting for my food and I didn't much care for that.

Listen! I can't wait to come back! 

Ambiance: I love the cafe vibes. Clean, two story with enough places to sit or do some work. Clean. 

Service: everyone was so helpful and attentive! 

Food: They have options for all dietary restrictions. listen... I can't wait to try the shrimp katsu sando again. Cooked to perfection, well seasoned and amazing texture. Don't get the started on the stuffed matcha pumpkin croissant! Amazing! Surprisingly it was not too sweet. The strawberry matcha latte was solid. 

Must try!

photos.caption: Shrimp & Japanese Tartar Katsu Sando with homemade sweet potato chips. Matcha Iced Strawberry Matcha Latte. Delicious

comment.text:
Cafe items? Amazing! Restaurant items? Just okay.

Cafe: I got the brown sugar latte and my wife got the strawberry matcha (FIRE). We also got the pistachio cream croissant and it was delicious.


Restaurant: I got the chicken katsu sando which was really good but pretty small/not filling enough for me. For $13-$15 dollars, I was expecting a pretty hefty sandwich but that wasn't the case. 

Overall, I think it's worth coming here for the cafe items as they are different and really good! It also looked like they had unique seasonal drinks which is always a plus. Would I recommend coming here for food? Nah, especially since there's other great options nearby.

Cheers!

i had drinks and lunch with a friend. the restaurant shares a space with the cafe in a somewhat strange configuration. 

the indoor seating is very close between tables. we sat outside on the covered patio, since it had more more room. the patio is quite close to the street and highway, so noise is a slight concern, but it wasn't too awful. 

the tables have QR codes from which you order. the online menu is a bit clunky to navigate, and very long, but you can order from the restaurant and cafe. our food was brought out in an irregular order - my friend's entree (matcha yogurt) then her appetizer, then both of our drinks, and finally my mentaiko stir fry noodles. it was very good but i feel like the order was a bit off putting. 

i also brought home a pork and cheese katsu sandwich and creme brulee croissant. The croissant was a bit bready but had delicious topping and cream filling. the sandwich was a bit dry and underfull, and i would probably not purchase again. however, i would certainly go back for the noodles and cafe space.

This spot pretty cool with all.things ramen and Japanese fares. It also has a coffee shop that's creative with its coffee and matcha drinks. I went for a matcha green tea which was pretty good with a tiramisu cream toast. My friends matcha tea with Matcha soft serve was delicious but the brown tea latte was pretty average. The creme Brulee pastry crossoint is a must try. 
Parking is validated for two hours in modera lot

photos.caption: Creme.brulee pastry. Must try. Crunchy on thr outside and perfect chewy texture
I tried Eisenger (toast wirh tiramisu. Cream)

comment.text:
What a chill spot!!! 

The drinks and matcha are great and there is so much seating available for studying or just sitting and meeting up with friends. This place is easy to walk to from city center and there is on street and garage parking on the same block.

Momonoki tonkatsu was fantastic! I love having a jammy ramen egg with my noodles with the fatty pork belly. 

The Okinawa brown sugar latte was so great on a cold day!

photos.caption: Iced Strawberry Latte, Iced Strawberry Matcha Latte, strawberry croissant
Fried Oyster Katsu Sando, Steak (Filet Mignon) Sando

comment.text:
Starting off with the positives; it's nearby Georgia Tech so it's a nice spot to study, grab a bite, hang out with friends, etc. Coming here, I've been told that they're known for their matcha related drinks, so with that information I got the matcha lemonade.  I should've known what to expect, but the taste did throw me off. The lemonade was tart, and even when I mixed the matcha and lemonade, it took me quite a bit to get used to. Still good, just took me off guard. They also have coffee menu items, bakery items, and non matcha or coffee items as well. Some menu items allow you to add alcohol in it, which was interesting to me. Service was amazing as well, and staff was super nice about suggesting drinks and informing us on where to sit. 
The downsides is that there is limited seating. Seeing that it's by multiple college campuses, seating is limited, especially with there being a restaurant as well. But that's pretty much the only downside, so don't let that stop you from trying here even if it's to get a drink and leave!!

Had the pork belly Ramen with a few add ins: corn, avocado, cabbage and some chilli for extra spice. Everything was delicious and very filling. The service was excellent. After our meal we crossed over to the cafe and ordered pasties and matcha beverages. Delicious we'd definitely go back .

In town for a conference and found this place. Ordered via QR code and the waitstaff brought the food. Had the beetroot latte (too powdery but not earthy), steak bowl (overcooked depsite asking for medium rare and lack of flavor), sesame lemon cheesecake (citrusy and not too sweet). It looks like they are short staffed and food came almost 20 minutes after. Rice was too wet and I wouldn't order that again. $18 was pricey for the amount of protein. 
Cheesecake $10 was the best and again a bit pricey.

This place is so cute and the upstairs study space is adorable. The outdoor space is quite nice too, just not as decorated. The only thing is, there aren't too many outlets at group tables. You kinda have to sit at the long table in a row to use the outlets. The matcha soft serve!!!!! So goddamn delicious. The matcha latte here is a little powdery :( but the taste is still pretty good. If you get the latte with the matcha soft serve on top, it tastes so good as the soft serve melts into it. The viral circular croissants are honestly amazing. They switch up the collection every now and then and they have these really unique flavors (lots of matcha stuff). The citrus chocolate one is 
They make the drinks pretty quick and the baristas are always so nice and chirpy. Always a great experience :)

photos.caption: Excited to try the circular croissant!

comment.text: My friends and I come here way too much to study and get a cute drink/pastry, it's honestly very bad for my wallet how good the strawberry matcha is here! Food is also delicious - ramen and rice bowls especially. Really aesthetic vibes, they have a restaurant/cafe seating area and an upstairs study/work area, perfect for long study sessions!

Sadly, left Momonoki dissatisfied today. Paid $19.86 all in for a salmon shiitake bowl with what i considered to be a small serving of salmon (maybe 1/4 cup) for that price. Also, the mushrooms were missing from the dish. Because you order from an app, interactions with service are limited, and it makes it kind of difficult/awkward to inform staff of any issues. Was disappointed in the visit overall.

Maybe just come here for the fun drinks. Would not recommend for the bowls, esp at the price point.

I came here for a very delayed lunch/early dinner on Friday. Thus, I was quite hungry. I ordered the brown sugar latte, the takoyaki, the matcha cream puff, and the Tsukemen. The brown sugar latte was not too sweet but I did expect something much sweeter given how other stores' versions taste. For appetizer, I got the takoyaki which were the perfect size. For my entree I got the Tsukemen, and this was more proof that I am NOT a Tsukemen girly. Finally, I got the cream puff with matcha custard for the dessert. I was dumb and thought it was a matcha-flavored puff that you could add strawberry custard to, but it's really just a regular ol' puff that you add either matcha or strawberry to.

As always, I love the seating options and that the store is divided into the cafe and restaurant. The servers were so attentive and kept checking on me because I was there for so long. I overheard the manager rally the team to prepare them for potential DragonCon customer rush, which was super awesome as a customer to know that they truly care about their service and wanting to go above and beyond.

photos.caption: Brown Sugar Latte, Takoyaki, Tsukemen, Matcha Cream Puff

comment.text:
DELICIOUS! My husband and I came here for an impromptu lunch. They have a cute bakery when you walk in, but we made our way to the tables. It's a QR ordering system - pretty seamless, but we had a great server that got water and answered our questions. My husband got the Peach Sumo Smash. He loved it (I am not a peach fan)! I was driving so I stuck with water. 

We had just missed brunch (it ends at 2 PM). For our entree, we both got a brothless ramen option. There were quite a few options we were choosing between. I settled on the Stir Fried Mentaiko Noodle which was utter perfection! The poached egg is very lightly poached, mixed with the sauce, this dish was super creamy. I also added some pork which paired wonderfully. My husband got the Sichuan Beef Mazemen. It has a little kick to it but not too spicy. It was good, but I thought mine was better. 

On our way out, we couldn't resist a croissant. We got the Yuzu and cream. A croissant with a creamy/yuzu center - what more can you ask for?! It was AMAZING! I would come back just for that, let alone a delicious meal. They also had a lot of really good coffee options, so I have sooooo many reasons to return. This is my new favorite cafe/ramen spot in ATL!

We didn't have any complaints with the food or the service but it was kind of hard to find a table right away. The dinosaur egg and seared pork belly bowl were delish. Pork belly was tender and had a robust flavor. I liked the creativity behind the dinosaur egg, the flavors worked together and created something delectable. Prices were reasonable.

Lovely little place! Its very beautiful, sitting outside is very nice! The service is quick and the employees are always very kind! 
Everything I've gotten has been delicious from here. I've tried both the cafe, and the main restaurant. The matcha cookie is so so good! They also have excellent ramen! Really do recommend this place if youve got a hankering for good Japanese sweets or a nice lunch. Very big servings, though, so go hungry!

This is one of the cutest little eateries I've found in Atlanta. The vibe is very cozy and perfect for an intimate coffee date or some quiet study time. I loved the different floors for studying in the shop. The baked items were delicious, I got just a classic chocolate chip cookie and it did not disappoint. I also ordered their hot pour over which came in the most unique rattan coozie of sorts. My friend ordered the strawberry fields matcha and loved it.  Service was fine. Overall a very cute eatery with good products.

Momonoki is a cute cafe style restaurant that serves many varieties of noodles, sandwiches, and more. Personally, I think it's has perfect lunch portions.
I got the Steak sando and it was nice and juicy. It was extremely filling. Flavor wise, while it was good it wasn't anything mind blowing but for the price of $20, I don't think I would order it again.
Overall, Momonoki is perfect for dates or just to grab a quick lunch. It is also connected to a cafe with many unique pastries including their famous spiral croissants which are amazing!

With the seemingly infinite stream of new casual restaurants popping up in Atlanta and serving quality cuisine, it can be a bit of a challenge to try them all, especially for someone who loves cooking at home and being on the road traveling.

Momonoki comes from the owners of Brush Sushi in Decatur, created by a husband and wife. Momonoki translates as "Peachtree" from Japanese, so it's undoubtedly paying tribute to the everything is peachy culture of the town and the street that seemingly connects everything. With a fully digital ordering system enabled with Apple Pay, payment is pretty easy, but there is certainly an argument to be made for and against the concept. I stand firmly within the "against it" crowd, preferring human interaction, attention and time away from a cell phone as much as possible during a meal. This forces you to be on the phone. While technology is great, there is a place for such concepts and Mononoki did not feel like that place.

The crowd here is largely dominated by Georgia Tech students coming in to study or grab a bite to eat. The space is somewhat industrial and there is a patio, which unfortunately is just too close to the interstate and major road to make it pleasant. The edamame here is out of this world, with a wonderful sauce and a perfect level of spice. The chicken katsu sandwich is also pleasant with good bread. Mushroom katsu is good as well. To finish off, a matcha soft serve ice cream is a must. All around, very solid food. I cannot personally say that with exception of Edamame I fell in love anything that would make me go out of my way to return, but I think liking even a couple things on the menu is a great thing as is.

It is important to keep in mind that the prices here will undoubtedly add up. Establishment's casual nature is not indicative of a low cost. I just did not feel that anything here was worth coming here to eat again, did not like the digital ordering method forcing you to pick up the phone everytime you want a beer and lastly just the general lack of ambiance. I did not hate it, I did not love it.

Loved the ambiance and food here! It was so easy to locate and to park. There was a garage right next to it which they validated parking for! 
My friend and I got the chicken sando which was sooo good! Cant wait to come back with another friend

photos.caption: Fried Chicken Sando w/ Ponzu Salad

comment.text:
Momonoki is connected to Momo cafe, and you can order items from both establishments when they're both open. 
Seat yourself, scan the QR code on the menu, then order and pay from your phone. 

My husband and I ordered from the brunch, cafe, and main menu. I really enjoyed the chicken & Croffle (croissant waffle). I love dark meat chicken, so this was perfect for me. Our friends ordered the regular Croffle, and it was topped with fruits and whipped cream. It looked amazing too.

We also tried the pork sando with curry dip, beet latte, and strawberry and cream croissant. I really enjoyed our variety of dishes. Would love to try their soft serve and other pastries next time! 

Parking: free parking at the deck right next to Momonoki (the deck with the gates that provides tickets). Don't get confused with the other parking deck that asks you to pay from your phone. Staff will provide 2 hour validation stickers if you ask.

photos.caption: Curry Dip Pork Katsu Sando, Beet Root Latte, Cucumber Wakame Seaweed Salad

comment.text:
When invited by our friends to come out of OTP, we jumped at the chance considering Momonoki had an interesting menu and we needed some outside time. Parking is kind of confusing so of course that's probably the first thing I have to go through.

**PARKING: There is a garage right next to the spot, make sure you don't get it mixed up with one that is further away, the garage is literally right next to the cafe. Momonoki will validate and that will be that.

Now, getting parking out of the way (because going downtown is crazy like that)... When we came in it seemed pretty cramped, but I liked that it was open seating and that they had outdoor heated seating. With the outdoor seating we had plenty of space and there were a lot more tables. 

Onto the food: Of course the thing to get here were the sandos. These are Japanese sandwiches, but the bread is fluffier because it's not your normal sliced bread. It's milk bread (well, it should be). The sandwich itself you have the option of what you want as far as protein. The Pork Katsu Curry was great, and I would definitely recommend it. The Cheese Pork Katsu was okay, but if I had to choose I would go with the curry version.

As my first time and going into the foray of croffles, they were great. It wasn't super sweet, but then I loved that there were all this fresh fruit. The croffle itself was great and I would definitely recommend this to anyone who wanted to try out croffles.

Overall, Momonoki isn't bad! I probably won't come here all the time, but for sure it's a place that I can mark off my list as a place I want to try. Come here if you're in the area, not afraid of dealing with traffic, or just want to try something different in your cafe experience.

This place was great for a first experience even though it was a little pricey for the food. 
_________________________________________________________

PARKING |

[The location is right across the street from NCR and there are parking deck options right next to the store.]
_________________________________________________________

EXTERIOR & INTERIOR |

[You won't be able to find the store from the sign because it is small, but once you are up close to the exterior of the store, it's pretty easy to find at that point. The interior is really nice and refreshing and has a lot of space to sit on the first floor.]
_________________________________________________________

IS IT CLEAN? |

[They do stay pretty clean the majority of the time which is absolutely great! ]

_________________________________________________________

FOOD & DRINKS |

[The place was great and easy to order because you had to just order on your phone. I got the Oyster sandwich was delicious and great. And their sweet potato chips were amazing! Probably my favorite. The food was great and fresh to the point, you fill relaxed at the end of your service.]
_________________________________________________________

SERVICE |

[The staff was very nice and helpful to help you get what you want, and work very efficiently to get all orders done with full care.]
_________________________________________________________

OVERALL |

[For the quality of the food was great, but the price is a little expensive for a sandwich that was $17 + tip. But the location is in downtown Atlanta, and some places can be expensive there. All in all, though, the food is well worth it if the cost was not an issue!]

This place has such an interesting feel. At first I thought I was walking into an outdoor market (even though there was indoor seating). The service was pretty good. Food was really good. I was skeptical about the dino egg, so I tried some of my friend's. Whatever to the actual egg, but that pork crispy outside I could eat as a standalone! It was so good. I wasn't crazy about the coffee soda, but it's because the fruit flavor clashed with the soda itself. If it was a cream soda it probably would've been amazing. My ramen was great. I added chicken and removed the pork belly, but the other pork was missing. The waiter was quick to give me the side of pork to add. 
It's also interesting because you order on their site almost as if you're ordering through Doordash. It's somewhat impersonal, but I honestly thought it was great because the service was on it. I think it's a tad pricey, but would still come back!

photos.caption: Spicy Miso Ramen with chicken added

comment.text:
Nice, casual spot in Midtown!

I stop my Momo Cafe all the time (one of my favorite matcha latte spots), but have never sat down and ate here. 

The ordering system is super fast and easy. They have a QR code at every table, so you can order online and they bring the food out to you. 

I got the Cheese Pork Katsu, which was really good! I got the sauce on the side, which was definitely not needed. The sandwich was super good, and the staff were attentive and friendly as well.

I really like the vibes too. It was mostly people studying or working. It would be a great place to grab food with friends, or to just sit for awhile and work. 

There is plenty of indoor and outdoor seating, and really nice upstairs area as well!

Place & atmosphere:
Momonoki is a two story cafe with the first floor being a dine-in served restaurant with ramen, rice bowls, and sandwiches. The second floor is meant for the cafe, and it has some seating for studying but the wifi cuts in and out. 

Cost & service:
Truthfully, the meals are expensive, and the taste is around a 6-7/10. Service is on the slower side as well. It is a great place to go to have dinner with friends if you don't care about the cost, but meals will cost around $20-30. The cafe is worth it if you're a big fan of iced strawberry matcha lattes, but overall Momonoki is just okay.

Ratings:
Iced strawberry matcha latte: 9.5/10
Matcha swirled ice cream: 10/10 (a must try)
Hot matcha latte: 5/10 (grainy, overly strong) 
Chicken kara-age bowl: 7.5/10 (very filling, probably my favorite ive had here)
Seared pork belly bowl: 7/10 (very saucy, also filling)
Ramens: 6.5/10 (mediocre, on the saltier side)
Salmon bowl: 5.5 (every salty and soupy)

photos.caption: Seared Pork Belly Bowl, matcha latte

comment.text:
I got something other than my usual (Avacado Shittake rice bowl) -- miso grits! The meal is definitely on the lighter side so if you are super hungry get something additional, but it's a reasonable quantity for the price.
It is warm and healthy which makes it super comforting. And if you're slightly iron deficient like me you will appreciate a tasty grits dish . Pork was very flavorful. I love any meal with some green color in it and the seaweed and green onions satisfied me visually. And the egg was perfectly poached! My tummy is happy.

photos.caption: Shiitake rice bowl and shiitake nuggets

comment.text: Everything here is delicious.  The delicious baked croissants are flaky and buttery and I really loved my chicken and waffles that had a Japanese twist and a croffle instead... definitely a gem of a place in ATL if you're looking for novel takes on comfort food.

photos.caption: Delicious croissants.  Fav was the yuzu

comment.text:
Been here a number of times and keep coming back. It's a calm vibe and has a cool coffee shop attached, with covered outdoor seating for the shop and restaurant. Ordering is easy and online via table QR codes, so you can add anything or check out at any time during your visit. The servers are friendly and efficient. I've tried almost all the appetizers, but my favorites are the dinosaur egg and shiitake nuggets. The katsu sandwiches are really good, well-portioned lunch. But I almost always get the ramen. I imagine all are great, but you definitely can't go wrong with the Momonoki Tonkotsu or Kakuni Spicy Miso Tonkotsu. 

For coffee, the Okinawa Brown Sugar Latte is great if you have a little bit of a sweet tooth. They also have baked goods which always look so good.

photos.caption: Okinawa Brown Sugar Latte, Cucumber Wakame Seaweed Salad, Kakuni Spicy Miso Tonkotsu

comment.text:
Momonoki was so fun! It is a cool restaurant with a cafe attached. My friend and I came, her for a beverage and treat and me for late lunch. It was so yummy!

I had the pork belly rice bowl. It was not a huge portion, but it was very delicious and tasted so fresh. Also got hot sauce on the side which was fantastic. My friend enjoyed her matcha and strawberry croissant, although I did not try them.

Service was good but a little confusing when we got in to know how to order / sit / the difference between the cafe and restaurant. We were also bummed they didn't have ice cream today. I will definitely be back!! Didn't even know this place existed!

Momonoki's menu items are very creative, fun, visually appealing; however, the taste never meets my expectation. I've previously tried their food and this time tried the round Matcha Croissant with Jasmine Cream. The Jasmine Cream was delicious but I could not taste the Matcha. The croissant itself was more bread like rather than buttery and flakey.

They've really upped their food game here! I got an egg and spam sando with mushroom and it was delicious! They have a brunch menu which I don't recall the last time I went. The service is quick and you order on your phone. The vibes are very cute and I'm surprised it's not always packed. There's a parking deck by it and some street parking. Definitely would recommend!

A fun and trendy multilevel cafe with great food and even better drinks! You scan a QR code to order and pay for your food, and the service is very quick. I walked in with a group of 4 around 5:30pm on a Friday, and it was busy but we were easily able to get a table. 
We tried their black sesame latte, matcha latte, taiwanese beers, momonoki tonkotsu ramen, spicy miso ramen, and soy milk miso ramen. We liked everything, and the portion sizes were generous. The ramen broths didn't particularly stand out, but were still enjoyable overall. Also, I have to say that our favorite was the taiwanese beers, especially the lychee beer. Tasted just like juice! 
This is a great place to come and get some work done (upstairs would be better for this) or hang out with friends!

This is hands down one of the best spots I ate when visiting Atlanta. We tried the sandos, the pastries and soda coffee. I've been telling everyone to try this place when they're in town. The entrees menu opened around 11AM, so if you go beforehand you can only order the cafe menu.

- Their pork katsu and oyster sando were incredibly delicious! They came with a choice of side: ponzu salad or sweet potato chips. I can never resist sweet potatoes! 
- The yuzu coffee soda was unlike any drink I ever had; a nice blend of sweet bubbly citrus and tad bitterness of coffee.
- I also had to get an assorted pastry box to bring back to NY, everything was super soft and delicious!

Everything I tried:
 Curry Dip Pork Katsu Sando & Ponzu Salad $14.50
 Fried Oyster Katsu Sando & Sweet potato chips $14
 Iced Yuzu Coffee Soda $6
 Matcha & Black Sesame Soft Serve $7.50
 Double Chocolate Chips, Pecan Cinnamon Roll, Matcha Mochi donut $13.50

photos.caption: yuzu coffee soda Top: Pork Katsu Curry with yuzu salad Bottom: Fried Oyster Katsu Sando with sweet potato chips
Fried Oyster Katsu Sando - incredibly delicious
Matcha & black sesame swirl - great flavor

comment.text:
PARKING: they validate parking for the parking lot immediately adjacent to the restaurant. If you check out their instagram, it shows you pictures of the particular parking garage. (If you turn into 8th Street, it is NOT the yellow parking garage.) parking validation is for two hours. 

Momo Cafe: There are two sets of doors. The one to the left is to Momo Cafe, the one to the right is to Momonoki. I think you can use either one. Momo Cafe is tight. There's limited seating upstairs. There's water and cups upstairs as well. 

RESTAURANT: 
You choose a table you want to sit at and on the table, there is a QR code. Scan the QR code, it'll take you to ToastTab. You order your food there. If you want to ask for recommendations or anything (I didn't), I assume you'll have to waive someone down.  I recall seeing six people there (including the guy behind working at the cafe). And you have to tip before you get to see the actual service you'll get. 

We ordered the Steak (Filet Mignon) Sando and Sichuan Beef Mazemen with ramen egg. 

I cannot say I'm impressed by the service. I watched our food sit on a table behind the counter as people walked by, I guess, to let our food cool down or because they prefer more to serve the stuffed croissants. However, I prefer my hot food to be served hot.  

The food finally arrived and I take pictures. That's when I noticed there was something shiny on the sandwich. A piece of plastic. We didn't say anything. Not worth the effort, to be honest, because I was already irritated that our food was just sitting there and the noodles were cool to touch when they were brought to the table. 

Another thing that annoyed me. The menu tells you what's in the Sichuan Beef Mazemen: "Stir fry beef, sesame peanut sauce, house chili oil, Sichuan pepper, chives, cilantro." Pictures showed bean sprouts but since it wasn't on the menu, we assumed bean sprouts are added on. Nope. It's already included. It's probably one-fifth of the dish.  Maybe it's just my misunderstanding of what the menu is telling me, but I wouldn't know that because waiters aren't there to communicate anything to you (ordering system). 

I am sure other people can speak to having great experiences and I am sure that this doesn't happen often, so if it's on your bucket list, don't let my experience stop you. Do I recommend this place for the food? Not really. It wasn't amazing or anything. Maybe if the food was warmer, it would've been better, but I wouldn't know and I'm not going to spend another $50 (including tip) to find out. (Recall, I had to tip before I received service.) Was it worth $50? No.  Is three stars generous? Yes, but I think (or hope) my experience is a one-off thing and wouldn't happen to most people.

photos.caption: My food sitting... waiting for someone to bring it to me. While people walked by it like it does not exist there.
Steak katsu sando. If you look closely, you can see it comes with a piece of plastic on top.
Close up of the piece of plastic on the steak katsu sando.
Sichuan Beef Mazemen plus a ramen egg.

comment.text: My husband, daughter and i popped in for lunch on a Sunday. The space is cute. Your order and pay from your table so no need to try and divide up your check at the end. We all ended up with Ramen!  Really nice broths. My husband loves spicy so he got the spicy ramen. Be warned. It is spicy!  But her loved it

Stopped by this place to work for a couple hours with a friend and got a snack from the cafe and lunch from the restaurant. Both were excellent! I got the citrus and chocolate croisant and a matcha mint chocolate drink from the cafe. The croissant was amazing, and the matcha was good, although there was wasn't any mint flavor in it. I also got a fried oyster Katsu sando from the restaurant for lunch and it was packed with flavor, not too heavy from the fried fish, and the side salad was seaweedy and delicious. Can't wait to check out their ramen next time.

photos.caption: chocolate citrus croissant and choco cha drink
Fried Oyster Katsu Sando and cucumber salad

comment.text: Very nice little corner restaurant in midtown. Friendly service and accommodating. The fried chicken katsu sando was good but I wish I had gotten the ramen.

We tried the curry dip pork katsu sando with the wakame cucumer salad and the croffle. Both were enjoyable, but the croffle is the item I would order again. 

Validated parking is shared with the Modera apartments. It is the deck with the gates. You have to ask the staff for a validation sticker. 

You can order and pay from your phone. No changing table in the bathroom.

I brought my schoolwork with me to do here while I ate but unexpectedly saw so many others doing the same. Very student friendly!! I thought this was just a regular restaurant but it's also a cafe. 
I did not realize that Momo Cafe & Momonoki were the same. They are connected and you order your food and drinks through the QR code at the table. It's super convenient. There is a second floor which has very little seating. It was full of students studying. There is also a covered and heated outside area. A lot of college students were here studying or just eating. The overall decor and ambiance were really cute and relaxing. The food is a little expensive, but I think it's worth it if you'll be sitting there for hours studying or socializing. It takes some time to come out, and it did taste very fresh. We ordered the Curry Dip Pork Katsu Sando with a side of sweet potato chips and the Pork Yuzu Shoyu Ramen with extra pork and a boiled egg. We loved the sandwich. It was so light and the curry dip was creamy and delicious. I did not like the sweet potato chips though. The ramen was also really good. It's not the best ever but the pork was very soft and had a nice overall flavor. The matcha cookie and matcha latte were OK.

Food - 5*
Most items are really nice and different including their desserts and pastries although they can have a lot of sold out items at a time.

Drinks - 4*
The basic drinks are fine but I've found multiple of their specialties to be not great.

Service - 3*
Usually fine although you order yourself from a QR code when you sit down, which usually wouldn't be a problem except it causes your server to only come around to bring your food and drinks. So if they mess up your order, you need to get out of your seat to talk to someone which has happened to me during a visit.

Ambiance - 5*
Really pretty and clean.

NYC prices for mediocre ATL coffee. They are super cute to take photos of. The upstairs area is a great place to work from home, but outlets and seating is limited. The pastries are decent but also pricey. Your drink comes out produced pretty quickly and there is a large selection of specialty drinks

A good spot to meet up with friends or get some studying done. They have free wifi with an upstairs loft area (limited seating) and the downstairs seating area is quite large with the covered patio available too. I've been here mostly to grab a pastry and coffee/tea.

I liked the mochi donuts, and was surprised to see the viral circular (suprême) croissants available. They've made their own version. The strawberry & cream and tiramisu & marscapone ones were yummy. I think they could have used a little more cream filling. Not bad at $6.50 each (they're $8+ in NYC)!

Parking: make sure to park in the garage that's closest to the cafe. Don't park in the one for the apartments (no parking ticket or gate). Momonoki will validate your parking for 2 hours, so you'll want to park in the correct garage!

Great place! I stopped here for lunch and coffee as I was passing through ATL. I had a Crispy Spicy Tuna plate and a Yellowtail Jalapeño rice bowl. Both were very good, the crispy spicy tuna was especially phenomenal! Grabbed a rosemary onion croissant for the trip home. 

Place was a bit busy when I came, but was very clean and organized. Staff were friendly and helpful, I really liked their online menu (scan a QR code).

Def would recommend -- I'll be back next time I pass through!

So...this was a very surprising (shocking?) experience for me.

I've been itching to try this place for a LONG time. I mean, just look at the juicy pics of their foods...and did I mention that I'm a huge fan of Japanese foods??

WELL. For starters...I came in after a trying time in traffic, as well as perplexed with their parking situation. I actually called prior to arriving at the restaurant, to ask about parking. Well, I was told that the parking garage was called "Modera" (?). Well, after nearly an hour-long traffic jam to get to this Midtown location (this area is basically a Cluster***k during rush hours), I finally get to this place...only to find a garage right next to the "Modera" sign, yet one that's NOT for Momonoki. In fact, this garage required a pre-paid parking ticket. I had to pay 6 bucks for 2 hours (but only after doing so online...their machine wasn't working!). Anyway, turned out that there were TWO parking garages, nearly next to each other...and again, the one located RIGHT next to the "Modera" sign was NOT the one. Thanks to the girl on the phone who did NOT specify-clarify this possible confusion, I ended up paying the parking fee (if I parked in the right garage, it would have been free-validated). So that's the initial bummer.

Then once I entered the restaurant, I was told to order electronically via their QR code...through their annoying ordering system. Basically I had to enter every information possible, including typing in my credit card numbers. WHAT a pain...not to mention a possible security risk (public internet area)! 
It was either this or the alternative of ordering in line...which they seemed somewhat reluctant to do initially (??). I was already in a mood when I entered the restaurant... then THIS?!? 

Also, must mention that this table I initially came upon was so dirty, I was basically cleaning it myself when one of their staff members noticed...and took over. BTW, the whole place just looked rather unkempt and dirty. 

Anyway, I couldn't decide, so ordered more foods than I should have. I ordered their Chicken Katsu Sando w/ Veggies, then this "Dry" curry dish that intrigued me. I also ordered their Black Sesame Latte. I actually felt somewhat hopeful at this point...having ordered some of what I thought would be "heavenly" eats. 

Sadly, more frustrations and disappointments. First of all, the Black Sesame Latte didn't even look like "Black Sesame" Latte...Rather, just a typical Latte w/ a few sprinkles of Sesame...which basically ruined their efforts at cafe art! OMGLOL?? While I liked the presentation of the Dry Curry, the beef had this funky taste...and I just did NOT like it at all. I had maybe had 3 spoonfuls? Good thing I ordered 2 entrees? Well, not that lucky! Not sure if they delivered the wrong order or what, but my Chicken Katsu Sando did NOT look or taste like Chicken Katsu (I ordered Chicken Katsu, but they delivered something else???). If it was Chicken, it sure had a weird taste to it...not the typical Japanese Katsu taste AT ALL. Even the Milk Bread was disappointing ...as it was so thin!! Again, I took maybe 3 few bites, and just gave up. I simply did NOT like ANYTHING I ordered...and that's a true rarity for me.

So yep, I paid about 42 bucks, including tip (for what, I don't know?)...for foods and drinks that I barely ate. Good thing the items weren't too pricey...but still, what a waste of my time (including traffic time!) and money (including parking!). *SIGH*

I thought this was an authentic Japanese bistro, but the foods just did not taste authentic to me. More than anything, the foods were very oddly flavored...which just tasted "funky" (wet, bitter/odd, and just all BLAAAH)! Was this an off day...or are they really this bad?? 

I REALLY thought I'd love this place...as I perused over their menu beforehand...but obviously for me, it was ALL a miss. Bad location, confusing parking, convoluted ordering system, dirty tables...and funky foods. 

Never again!

photos.caption: Black Sesame Latte (Are you kidding me???)

comment.text: Came here for brunch- everything was aesthetic but more importantly tasty! My favorite was the croissant waffle. The pork belly and ramen egg were also cooked perfectly

Momonoki is a restaurant that sells Japanese inspired dishes. I really like the modern interior design and minimalistic aesthetic. The inside features natural colors such as whites, greens and light wooden browns. There are also a lot of plant decorations, which is a nice touch and adds to the natural aesthetic of the space. The restaurant has its own mini cafe, outdoor seating, as well as a second floor. The second floor makes for a great study spot. A waiter can take your order, or you can scan a QR code and place your order online. Service is great. The waiter was very attentive and always came by to refill my glass when I was running low on water. 

I always order the same thing when I come to Momonoki because I finally found something that tastes good and isn't disappointing. I've had a lot of bland items off the menu, one of them being the Momonoki Tonkotsu Ramen. I will never order ramen from Momonoki again because of how lackluster the broth and toppings were. It's definitely not worth the price (minimum $16). Below are my reviews for the items I had: 

*Chicken Kara-Age Bowl ($13.00) - The chicken karaage has definitely improved since the last time I visited. Sometimes the chicken is dry, but this time it was flavorful and tender. The karaage is seasoned with some type of spicy powder, which isn't something I remember it having, but I like it and it gives the dish some personality. What hasn't changed is the ratio of rice to toppings. When my friends and I order rice bowls, we are always left with so much rice. I'm not saying that the solution is to give less rice because I love rice, but I wish there were more toppings to go with it instead of eating it by itself. For $13, I'm not expecting 10 pieces of chicken karaage, but at least one more piece would be nice, or at the very least more of the wasabi mayo sauce to coat the rice at the end and make it more tasty. You can add more sauce for $1, but I don't think it's worth it. I think the bowl should come with slightly more sauce to begin with to coat the rice at the end. This bowl feels like it's doing the bare minimum, yet this is also the only thing I enjoy eating when I come here, which I think says a lot about the menu options.
*Matcha Soft Serve Cup ($6) - Very smooth soft serve. Great matcha flavor; it has a subtle earthy bitterness. I personally wouldn't get this flavor again because it was a bit more bitter than I would've liked, but it was delicious and I recommend it.
*Strawberry & Cream Soft Serve Cup ($6) - Also very soft and smooth texture. I enjoyed this flavor more than the matcha. It tastes just as you'd expect a strawberry soft serve to taste, sweet and tastes like yummy strawberries. It is also a beautiful pink color, which made me enjoy it even more.
(I really wanted to try the Yuzu Sorbet or Black Sesame Soft Serve, but unfortunately, both were out of stock.)

TL;DR: The inside of Momonoki is a beautiful space, but the food isn't as impressive (especially for the price) and the flavor is lacking.

photos.caption: (left to right) Matcha Soft Serve Cup, Strawberry & Cream Soft Serve Cup

comment.text:
Happy hour 3-5pm!! 
Been here 10+ times now. Great place for a quick bite between work times and for lunch. The service is fast and food is menu is small enough to choice. The sandwich are all on milk bread which makes them hefty. I recommend the chicken karage sandwich with sweet potato ships. Definitely do try the cafe's matcha brownie and cookie- they are so fudgy and good!

Beyond Katsu sandwich was very good, and came with a generous portion of seaweed salad. Fun selection of Asian beers as well - all very fruity tho. Underwhelming service - had an order on the web setup going and took a long time to bring out even basic orders, like 10 minutes for drinks. Nice patio. Would go back and try some ramen.
